Contradiction in the Neoliberal Academe:

A Critical Case Study of the University of Auckland Administration

Java Grant

The University of Auckland

November 2022

Content Warning

The content of this research is not explicit but includes themes of exploitation, financial precarity, and the distortion of reality (‘gaslighting’).

Introduction

This research establishes if neoliberal university administrations are a reliable source of self-reflective discourse through a case study of discourse around the University of Auckland (UoA) during the New Zealand (NZ) university staff strikes on October 6th, 2022. The strike proved an excellent nexus for issues affecting university staff across NZ. Underinvestment in universities and staff left the academe vulnerable. The pandemic and subsequent inflation led to the strike. The strike provided social permission for participants to challenge the image of universities produced by the administrations. Discourse critiqued both specific university actions and underlying value systems, breaking imposed ideas of the academe. Suddenly “functions and mal-functions, actions and in-actions are all on open display” (Matthewman, 2015, p. 15).

This research evaluates the rhetoric and actions of the UoA administration, the Tertiary Education Union (TEU) leadership, and staff to ask if university administrations in NZ act consistently with their proclaimed values. This research applies critical university scholarship and deductive reasoning to evaluate claims and actions about the strike presented in news articles, social media posts, reports, and public statements to analyse competing conceptions of UoA and their implications. Topics include conceptions of who bears the university identity, the reality of the administration’s values, the necessity of administrative (in)actions, and consequences for radical reconceptions of higher education.

NZ universities employ 36,230 full-time staff (Education Counts New Zealand, 2022) and have an “income of over $4 billion per annum” (Universities New Zealand, n.d., para. 2). The University of Auckland (UoA) captures 25% of NZ tertiary enrolments (Education Counts, 2021). It ranks well internationally (the University of Auckland, n.d.-b). UoA administration claims to be leading NZ; “[UoA] gained 30% of the [national] funding overall, thereby confirming its position as the nation’s premier research institution” (the University of Auckland, n.d.-d).

This research finds the neoliberal UoA administration provides unreliable narrations of events to maintain power structures, undermining the social value our universities offer. The neoliberal academe increasingly demands neoliberal justifications for research. Academic labour that reimagines higher education must negotiate dominant conceptions of university operations. Establishing administrations as unreliable frees academic labour from negotiating ideology to “acknowledge the limits of existing universities and seek alternative, and/or radically transformed forms of the university” (Stein, 2020, para. 3). By extension, this research operates in the interests of those oppressed by hegemonic power operating within university administrations.

In the process of domination, administrations harm staff with poor working conditions, employment precarity, and a lack of respect. Instead, NZ universities serve the state and capital (Readings, 1999). Critical literature identifies UoA’s 2013-2020 strategic plan as fulfilling the tenets of Academic Capitalism (Wright & Shore, 2017), appropriating value from and exploiting staff and students.

Context

Symbolic structures order our perceptions and enable meaning-making (Bourdieu, 1991). The symbolic order is the structures shared/enforced by society (Lacan & Fink, 2007). Symbolic structures produce tools that interpret experience, such as our self-conception. Symbolic structures conceive of universities in particular ways, guiding our perception of their purpose and quality. The purpose of universities is interpreted differently by stakeholders. Critical symbolic structures reveal the university as an ideological apparatus for capital and the state. Where social power inequalities influence administrations' goals, universities maintain power structures. Uncritical structures, like vague narratives of ‘excellence’, are dispersed by administrations in such interests. Neoliberal capitalism leads universities toward stratification, exploitation, and maintaining capitalist economic systems using marketisation, rent-seeking, and surplus extraction. However, the transition to the neoliberal university is not hegemonic. By providing alternatives to neoliberal doctrines, academics are “part of the ‘grit’ that prevents the imagined neo-liberal world system functioning smoothly” (Clarke, 2004, p. 44).

Well-being and purpose of university

Definitions of well-being are deeply tied to conceptions of universities, guiding what it means for individuals, universities, and society to ‘be well’. Well-being connects to the academe “in the curriculum, in pedagogy, or in the institution’s structure or priorities” (Harward, 2016, p. 4). Well-being and higher education matter for students, faculty, and democratic civic society, as a component of “the greater purpose of higher education and to the wholeness of those participating” (p. 3).

Well-being is a complex construction of values, such as a sense of belonging and health, and has two traditions of use. Hedonic conceptions view well-being as an empirical measure of feelings (Harward, 2016). Eudaemonic conceptions understand well-being as a relational activity of ‘being well’ and is often overlooked in learning. Institutional well-being measures the opportunities it provides to participants and engagement with the community (Harward, 2016).

Attending to well-being is to realize a fundamental dimension of the purpose of higher education! And it is the unique responsibility of higher education to provide the multiple opportunities for the manifestation of greater purpose. Beyond schooling and acculturation, higher education is the context that most clearly reveals the interdependency of learning and the civic, the paths for realization of self and its dependency on other, as well as skills and values connected to work and service, leadership and meaningful life choices. (Harward, 2016, p. 7)

Serving capitalist structures as the purpose

Capitalist modes of value extraction redesign universities, degrading the academe by re-articulating people as ‘human capital’, corporatising academia, maintaining social hierarchies, and exploiting staff. Neoliberalism delegates the academe for skill provision for the economy; therefore, universities focus on measurable skills desired by capital (Block et al., 2012; Harward, 2016). The neoliberal reform of people as human capital operating with market values (Shenk, 2015) proposes that the purpose of higher education is purely utilitarian. Therefore, universities should emphasise learning exploitable by capital (Harward, 2016). The premise of higher education for democratic enhancement, critical social reflection, and socially beneficial research has devolved to education as human capital development. Administrations reduce staff to labour, students to customers, and “individual gain is prized over any public good” (Harward, 2016, p. 7).

Optimising for neoliberal conceptions of success, universities must prioritise maximising income and minimising expenses over education and research. Consequently, universities have developed a ‘third mission’ of commercialisation which enclose knowledge through intellectual property rights (Lewis & Shaw, 2017), guiding academic labour in line with dominant power structures. Higher education is increasingly provided for capital rather than for education and liberation.

Due to its stratifying capacity, “A university education has never been a universal right anywhere” (Beilin, 2016, p. 12). Western education, knowledge, and science have continually developed to capitalism’s needs. The post–World War II needs of businesses and the state for a well-trained workforce (Beilin, 2016) drove higher education expansion as USA production shifted from manufacturing to white-collar professions, requiring post-secondary training (Beilin, 2016). Despite social movements to democratise higher education in the 60s, mid-70s economic downturns empowered economic liberalism to undo advances (Beilin, 2016).

Without wrap-around support, higher education is a precarious venture. Higher education stratifies students from disadvantaged backgrounds (Point & Associates, 2022), and by extension, from privileged social positions:

  • Students living in rental accommodation were more likely to have paid employment (75%) than students not renting (65%) (p.25).
  • The shift to online learning did not serve many students well – only 71% were able to continue their studies during lockdown. Furthermore, 18% did not have access to a laptop or computer, another 22% had to share their device with someone else, and 19% did not have a reliable internet connection (p.21).
  • 70% of Māori and 75% of Pasifika did not have family or whānau who support[ed] them financially in their study (p.30).

Precarious employment

Although companies draw upon notions of wholesome values of family and manaakitanga, many exploit precarious workers (Galic, 2019). While our broader social structures exacerbate the precarity of higher education for students, our administrations are rigging the employment relationship for precarious working conditions and fleeting academic relationships. Competitive pressure requires exploiting staff by reducing pay, increasing workloads, and minimising contractual obligations to staff, such as employment security. In the academe, there exists “a dual labour market, with [...] a shrinking protected research elite and a large precarious research class” (OECD, 2021, p. 15). While precarious workers love to work, management does not appreciate their labour; they receive low wages and struggle with occupational violence (Galic, 2019).

There are extensive well-being implications of precarious work (McKee et al., 2017). Employment precarity encroaches upon staff’s lives. One-quarter of precarious staff provide an 8 out of 10 personal stress assessment (Simpson et al., 2022). Workers with long hours have degraded bonds with friends and insufficient time with families, particularly those with children, existing precariously; “deprived of existential stability and dispossessed from making one’s own history” (Galic, 2019, p. 164).

Employers systematically produce precarious working conditions, such as casualising workers’ contracts (Galic, 2019). These systems reflect Paulo Freire’s (1970) analysis of oppressive education, in which progression in established hierarchies replaces conceptions of true liberation, which seem the only opportunity for non-precarity (Galic, 2019). Unionised staff, by recognising the precariousness of each other, consistently and successfully fight against employment precarity (Galic, 2019). Multinationals and large employers have power and influence, transforming corporate welfare into social welfare; therefore, battling precarity is a crucial goal (Galic, 2019). Galic (2019) proposes more robust state engagement in providing unconditional support for vulnerable workers and unions, rejecting the neoliberal discourse of ‘choice’, which would diminish precarious employment in NZ.

Social good as the purpose

Traditional conceptions of universities align them with the goals of social good. Universities are critical in maintaining and developing society with the legislative obligation to be the ‘critic and conscious’ of society (Education Act, 1989). However, many see higher education as failing its greater purposes, “[retreating] from its unique purpose in an open society to be counter-normative—to be critical, if not contrarian, of convention” (Harward, 2016, p. 7). Effective representative democracy requires understanding social powers and problems, “a key premise of public secondary and higher education in the West” (Brown, 2015, p. 176). Thus the downfall of broadly accessible and affordable higher education under neoliberalism “threatens democracy itself” (Brown, 2015, p. 175).

The 1960s cemented the progressive missions of education and research in NZ higher education, beginning massification through government funding (The New Zealand Productivity Commission, 2017), and expanding available subjects greatly (University of Auckland, n.d.-a). Additionally, UoA brought “a new emphasis on staff research. Many of the new and younger academics became very active researchers, reflected in the growing lists of staff publications” (The University of Auckland, n.d.-a, para. 14). The individual and societal benefits of higher education are undeniable. Two years after graduation, bachelor’s degree holders earn an additional 18% above the median income, 20% above in five years, and 25% above in ten (Ministry of Education, 2022). However, the returns extend beyond financial, with evidence showing better health and lifestyle outcomes for those with tertiary qualifications (Ministry of Social Development, n.d.).

These values remain in legislation and prevent complete subversion of the academe. The legal securing of academics’ freedom and obligations of NZ universities remains a valuable backstop to the degradation of the institution.

Neoliberalising the academe

The TEU strike is a point of disruption for neoliberalism at the university. As a defining feature of our time (Harvey, 2005), universities in NZ are not untouched by neoliberal discourse. Hegemonic neoliberalism envelops all of life, imposing symbolic structures which measure all things economically (2005). Ideological apparatuses become “a medium for disseminating neoliberal rationality beyond the economy, including to constitutive elements of democratic life” (Brown, 2015, p. 151). The neoliberal doctrine aligns well-being with economic liberty, secured by private property, free markets, and free trade (Harvey, 2005; Morrissey, 2013). As the ‘Neo-Conservative Laboratory’ (Bruneau & Savage, 2002), neoliberal dogma has an incredible hold over NZ and is now hegemonic in many western nations. The neoliberal project has reshaped our culture and workplaces as a testing ground (Blackmore, 2017).

Academic capitalism

This research understands the incentive structures for NZ university administrations as academic capitalism, investigating the influence upon social goals identified in the TEU strike. Academic Capitalism scholarship traces and articulates the impact of market and market-like activities on the academe (Slaughter & Rhoades, 2010). Neoliberal projects demand the enclosure of knowledge through intellectual property rights for rent-seeking, such as Third Mission activities (Lewis & Shaw, 2017). Neoliberalism determines the value of information by its ability to be monetised (Beilin, 2016), and pressure to be able to commercialise research and education is reshaping teaching and research. Market-like behaviours align university operations with capitalist symbolic value structures (Lewis & Shaw, 2017).

Since the 1970s, Neoliberalism has rearticulated universities to constrain the possible action within the academe (Beilin, 2016). To achieve success according to mechanisms such as market conditions must, in turn, “invent market systems” (Harvey, 2005, p. 65). Cris Shore (2010) identifies the responsibilisation of NZ universities to manage risk and maintain global competitiveness by broadening the roles of staff and student experience in academia. The UoA administration commodifies students and staff (Slaughter, Campbell, Holleman & Morgan, 2002), making research transactional (Readings, 1999). These policies undermine public universities’ effectiveness and social return on investment (Universities New Zealand - Te Pokai Tara, 2022). Neoliberal universities’ priorities do not naturally align with their stakeholders. The associated consolidation of capital is in the interest of university administration and the controllers of capital (Marx & Fernbach, 1991), not for students or faculty. Limited and discretionary funding for postgraduate students demonstrates conflicts of proclaimed values of student well-being and imposes capitalist measures of educational achievement. The role of universities in society is increasingly unclear; the declining power of the nation-state transforms universities into transnational corporations and provides usage of ‘excellence’ as a measure of academic and teaching success (Readings, 1999).

Our key institution, UoA, is increasingly engaged in corporate-like behaviours, and capitalist goals guide how the administration expands and redefines the responsibilities of the university beyond education and research. Consequently, there are increasing charges for education, commercialisation of research, capital investments in luxury student facilities, and valorisation of commercialisation skills in academic contracts (Lewis & Shore, 2017). UoA provides healthcare, career and academic guidance, entertainment/hospitality, and employment (The University of Auckland, n.d.-a; n.d.-b; n.d.-g), constructing new roles for NZ universities. The growth in universities’ services reflects the broadening scope of institutions as they negotiate a competitive market connected to broader trends in the neoliberal academe of rent-seeking, value extraction, and free market competition.

Marketisation

Enthusiasm for neoliberalism inside education originated from ties between academic performance and the economy, directing resources to economic concerns. This introduced themes such as ‘excellence’ and the commodification and financialisation of universities (Buschman, 2020). Education and research for their own sake no longer justify the university’s existence (Buschman, 2020). Universities must negotiate with the state to compensate for externalities. Otherwise, they must extract surplus from students and staff through knowledge economy goals, like knowledge enclosure (Tertiary Education Commission, 2016) and monopoly rent. Neoliberal structures have expanded beyond the commercial and policy realm and into democracy. Markets subvert conceptions of citizenship, liberal education, community, rights, and dissent. Consequently, administrations restrict universities’ capacity as ‘critic and conscious’ to appease capitalist power structures (Lewis & Shore, 2017).

Largely imposed on UoA via state policies, marketisation policies in the higher education sector demand universities to behave as economic actors despite being public institutions subsidised ostensibly in control of the state for the benefit of the public. The UoA administration has obliged, continually expanding international student enrollment (only dropping 5.5% during the COVID-19 pandemic), increasing vulnerability to competition for students with universities internationally. UoA pours incredible resources into buildings and facilities attractive to wealthy international students, spending $595 million on The Human Sciences Building and Recreation and Wellness Centre, both due 2024 (The University of Auckland [Administration], 2020).

Demobilising alternatives to neoliberalism

Obscuring power

Specific language crushes alternative ways of being and thinking. Neoliberal texts carry interpretive and problem-solving structures (Bourdieu, 1991). Neoliberal language emphasises power relationships between the dominator and dominated, reframing democratic governance to problem-solving, classes to ‘stakeholders’, laws to ‘guidelines’, regulation to ‘facilitation’, and genuine policing and enforcement to ‘standards’ and ‘codes of conduct’ (Brown, 2015, p. 129). Ideology obscures power from relations (Brown, 2015). For example, the appropriation and dissolution of feminist values through the misinterpretation by the symbolic order of mainstream education literature (Blackmore, 2017). Ideological frameworks reinterpret radical or challenging language beyond radical ideas to create solutions that maintain hegemonic power structures, including maintaining established university institutions. Such attempts reframe human well-being as eating fruit while being exploited, particularly when it alliterates.

Ideology

Marxist interpretations of ideology identify representations of reality, creating meaning in service of power (Block et al., 2012). Advancing the Marxian theories of the state, Louis Althusser defines the ideological state apparatus. While the Repressive State Apparatus operates by “securing by force (physical or otherwise) the political conditions of the reproduction of relations of production”, Ideological State Apparatuses wield ideology (Althusser, 1970).

Capitalist ideology competes with the critical conscience obligations of the university. The skills agenda recognises that universities increasingly operate for skill provision (Coleman & Pankl, 2020), redefining student success into the framework of serving capital. Due to economic competitiveness, students increasingly understand themselves as human capital and expect increased financial returns from higher education, exacerbated by punitive measures for financially disadvantaged students, including expenses and limitations on loan access (Kenny, 2012). Internal and external to the academe, credentials are what successful education is, a precursor to workplace success (Beilin, 2016). These dominant conceptions of success diverge from traditional notions and clash with critical education (2016). Consequently, students are financially rewarded for avoiding critical education, instead increasing their exploitability under capitalism.

Keywords

One tactic for neoliberal hegemony has been the nestling of business keywords and framings in the public sector, particularly in higher education (Block et al., 2012). Neoliberal keywords extend economic descriptors to other social fields, such as education, health, and social services. Marnie Holborow (2013) identifies the prevalence of ideological construction within universities via keywords, terms with ideologically negotiated meanings (Block et al., 2012, p. 35), which reframe and limit the reader’s possible structuring of reality. Terms of identity, such as ‘student’ or ‘teacher’, present specific structures to the university which maintain systems of domination, such as the banking model of education (Freire, 1970). This framing reduces the relationality of education as transactional and oppositional to a manufactured other (Clarke & Newman, 1997). The ideological construction of these keywords operates to reconstruct the symbolic order in the vision of those powerful enough to do so. As Karl Marx (1845) asserts, ‘The ideas of the ruling class are in every epoch the ruling ideas’ (para. 21).

Suppression

Since the 1970s, elites in developed economies intentionally attacked the ability to dissent against a systematic commodification of culture (Coleman & Pankl, 2020). The United States attempts to globally hegemonise neoliberal values through international institutions (Deacon, 1997). Celebration of individuality and freedom obfuscate power, limiting how free individuals can operate (Coleman & Pankl, 2020). Financial organisations, such as the World Trade Organization and World Bank, install neoliberal worldviews upon vulnerable nations, de-mobilising ‘alternative modernities’ with force, including “military, economic, political, cultural and discursive power” (Clarke, 2004, p. 30). By implementing market systems, these organisations released international competition, which forces economics into command, denying political choice. Through this model, “neo-liberalism tells stories about the world, the future and how they will develop – and tries to make them come true” (Clarke, 2004, p. 30).

Neoliberalism develops tools that abstract existence into finance, like carbon credits, ethical obligations, brand recognition, and influence, founding  ‘routes to market’ (Clarke, 2004), such as privatisation, outsourcing, and market creation (external and internal). Neoliberalism depoliticises the public realm, presenting the market as an efficient decision-making tool that mitigates critical thought in favour of financial evaluations (Clarke, 2004). No thought is needed if marketisation is assumed optimal. Anything outside economic evaluation is ruled inappropriate or irrelevant (Clarke, 2004). Such objectivist frameworks impose singular interpretations of reality through denial, defusion, or displacement of political conflict and alternative ways of being (Clarke, 2004). The New Zealand Government utilises measurement to liberalise higher education, “Creating new conditions for competitive success (e.g., in school recruitment, ‘performance’ evaluation, and bidding for ‘extra’ resources)” (Clarke, 2004, p. 36).

Financial institutions and international digital corporations, such as Facebook and Twitter, undermine democratic systems worldwide, exacerbating economic and political inequalities and profiting from the ruins of the 2016 USA election. The expenses of which “widespread mistrust, polarisation, tribalisation, and a culture of growing unreason” (Buschman, 2020, p. 158) bear down upon public institutions (2020).

Alternative ways of teaching and research threaten the hegemony of neoliberalism. Neoliberalism maintains dominance through alliances and de-mobilising alternatives via ideology (Clarke, 2004). This work requires politicking, propagandising and mobilising power and privilege. Ideology is inherently repressive, devaluing opposing discourses to align subjects with a specific, ostensibly truthful understanding of reality (Santisteban & Jones, 2022). Neoliberalism must suppress critical education, which threatens power, providing language to challenge and name alternatives to existing systems. By understanding the role of power, students can challenge the social forces in their lives (Coleman & Pankl, 2020) and participate in solidarity movements.

Critique as resistance

While neoliberalism may appear all-consuming and natural to us in the west, “from elsewhere, it more obviously resembles one way of constructing capitalist modernity” (Clarke, 2004, p. 30). Neoliberal ideology continues to be negotiated by staff and students, and historically, revolutionaries have succeeded in the systems they later challenged with power gained through conventional success (Beilin, 2016). Through naming injustice and questioning imposed values, critics inspire a pedagogy of hope: that educators can intentionally create space for democratic thinking, critical imagination, and resistance to authoritarianism (Coleman & Pankl, 2020).

Strategies for critique

Neoliberal institutions have failed to maximise social utility and increase personal freedoms, which were used to legitimise the neoliberalisation of the academe. John Welsh (2020) identifies the reversal of production, redistributing wealth closer to the political economy of feudalism.

This research utilises a critical strategy established in work by Welsh (2020) and David Harvey (2005), where analysis critiques neoliberalism on its terms. By holding neoliberal institutions accountable to claims of prosperity, quality of life, and enhancement of production, we can measure the contradiction of promise and delivery. Using the language and frameworks of neoliberalism to establish contradictions is an immanent critique analysing the policy and politics rather than trusting the regime (Clarke, 2004). By demonstrating that the neoliberal university administration is an unreliable narrator, we enable radical scholarship to focus on criticality rather than negotiating ideology.

Research plan

Positionality statement

I hold an intersecting position between students and faculty at UoA. My recent undergraduate degree and role as a tutor provide experiential knowledge contextualised with texts by other university staff and scholarship, such as academic capitalism.

While I may symbolically claim an ‘insider’ status, few academics can be reduced to my experience. I, for example, do not support a family or experience the obligations of most academics to publish or develop curricula. Lejla Voloder and Liudmila Kirpitchenko (2016) state that, as an insider researcher, I am "particularly conscious of the ethical expectations of research output" (p. 6). However, my insider status did not influence the qualitative data, as I entirely utilised secondary sources.

Methodology

As universities possess different roles and perceptions by various groups, this research utilises an interpretive methodology that contrasts the perspectives in the discourse of the university, a location of power struggle. This project grounds itself in constructivist epistemologies. This grounding enables the project to see systems of understanding as socially developed, hegemonic narratives (Berger & Luckmann, 1966). This research takes a critical-interpretivist-constructivist hermeneutic approach to analyse discursive data, informed by the notion that narratives and relationships are established through communication to identify the reality structuring functions of the UoA administration. Constructivist articulation of understanding as socially constructed applies well to institutionalised education, as such an organisation is a social decision rather than a natural occurrence.

‘Critical’ describes the intention to interpret the purpose of the texts, including the symbolic structures embedded within which maintain power structures. Any form of communication implicitly places meaning in conversation with other texts (Kress, 2012).  However, representations are always the result of multimodal meaning-making across media, even when they do not always converge to a single sense of the concept (Lemke, 2012). Comprehension demands understanding which structure is dominant and the roles each serve (Kress, 2012).

The epistemology of constructivism proposes that all knowledge is created, not discovered (Baxter & Jack, 2015). Importantly, using the interpretivist paradigm to create text through the interpretation of texts is vulnerable to bias (Kress, 2012). As university administrations did not revise their position within the sample, this concern is minimised. However, varying interpretations may exist between the texts produced by the diverse critical authors. Due to the nature of the academe, there is a large sample of explicit critical commentary, and the fraction of texts which are both sparse enough in meaning to require significant interpretation, as well as being incorrectly contextualised, is minimal.

As this project is interpretive, the structures of the researcher interpret the data, tying insights to a subjective interpretation of discourse. Therefore the influence of interpretation is minimised in various ways. Firstly, a positionality statement empowers the reader to evaluate insights cautiously. Secondly, my socialisation within NZ and participatory experience, with mindfulness of subjectivity, increase the likelihood of intended and nuanced interpretations of texts. Familiarity with relevant discursive structures originates from experience and literature, enabling informed recognition of cues, such as language or positionality of the author, for appropriate interpretation of the intention of texts, which “realise the interests of their makers” (Kress, 2012, p. 36).

This research uses Gunther Kress' multimodal discourse analysis (MMDA), which builds on Michel Foucault's discourse analysis, to study the construction of ideological discourse by the UoA administration. Constructing upon Foucault’s discourse analysis, MMDA shares the ability to identify the relationship of ‘social givens’ and language (Kress, 2012) and “to know what kinds of discourses were possible about a given topic” (Kress, 2012, p. 80). MMDA is well-suited for this purpose because it can take into account non-linguistic texts, such as action or inaction, which can strongly represent values and motivation (Kress, 2012).

Method

This study evaluates the reliability narratives via the juxtaposition of sample texts, which co-develop the symbolic construction of UoA. Such constructions are evaluated upon their consistency with other sampled structures, developing coherent constructions of UoA. This process enables second-order analysis, in which texts inform the interpretation of one another (Shkedi, 2004). A second-order analysis is helpful for sparse data, such as symbolic structures and inexplicit language, like ‘excellence’. Ideological domination obscures alternative viewpoints. Thus texts and scholarship can contextualise the interpretive process, providing space for obscured perspectives.

Collection

The texts for analysis come from Twitter posts containing ‘#TEUstrike’ or ‘#TEUonStrike’ and the associated Twitter accounts, followed by a search for relevant texts in official publications and reports from organisational bodies associated with UoA, such as the administration, the TEU, and Universities New Zealand.

The #TEUstrike posts are helpful by their direct association with disaster in the NZ academe, revealing that social relations were thrown into sharp relief (Matthewman, 2015). The tweets articulate alternative conceptions of university administrations. Texts produced by the administrations are presented with the identity of UoA, which is a particular value statement by the administration. These texts present the structures and beliefs held by the administration.

Analysis

Reconstructing models of UoA is achieved by combining various structures embedded within the texts. As the Twitter discourse is reactionary to the (in)action of the administration, there are likely two dominant conceptions of the university, the one offered by the administration and the one broadly understood by critical academics and the TEU. These conceptions are critically evaluated against one another, scholarship, and any empirical evidence from the sample, such as financial figures. The evaluation of the constructions of UoA works to establish whether the administration contributes to a coherent and socially useful conception and reality of the university.

This process works to unravel the inherent power “involved in the making, recognition and attribution of coherence in a text” (Kress, 2012, p. 36) to identify if the administration is trustworthy in its account of events.

Process

  1. Gathering the initial texts using Twitter’s search function, filtering for tweets containing #TEUstrike and other associated texts from the publishing accounts, replies, and tweet threads.
  2. Categorisation of texts according to a topic, such as wages, inflation, and the value of academic work
  3. Gathering documents that discuss the topics, such as news articles, reports, policy, marketing, and public statements.
  4. Compose co-constructed models of the university through authors who share a coherent symbolic structure of the university.
  5. Apply academic literature to the constructed models to interpret their reliability and consequences.
  6. Compare the claims and values of the administrative powers to the scholarship-informed interpretation.

Limitations

Invoking our sociological imagination, we can identify the pattern in particular and connect these ‘events’ to institutions' ongoing, systemic failure to support and provide for all their stakeholders. The events analysed here are manifestations of ongoing processes rooted in the values that the university administration holds regarding its purpose, value, and relationships, however, as an interpretive work only comprised of sparse secondary data, this research may not comprehend aspects of how the university is imagined beyond its presentation in texts.

Additionally, this research abstracts away the intersectionality of many issues presented within the sample that can not fit into this paper. This paper is not comprehensive of the financial and cultural concerns of neoliberal academic employment at the university. It can only offer a glance at some issues the academic workforce faces.

This research is limited to the University of Auckland, however, as the largest and leading New Zealand university (Universities New Zealand, 2017; the University of Auckland, n.d.-c), it is appropriate to understand how New Zealand engages with its universities broadly. A complete understanding of everything the university has said and done would enable the most informed praxis. However, there are diminishing returns to excessive detail and context. Instead, this research identifies broad trends at the university through examples in discourse from the October 6th strike at the University of Auckland.

Discussion

Competing constructions

As expected, texts generally expressed one of two dominant conceptions of UoA: one offered by the administrative powers and one negotiated by staff and the TEU. The conception offered by administrations (administrative conception) is utopic but inconsistent with that provided by staff, academic scholarship, and much of the administration’s data and previous administrative conceptions. In juxtaposition, the conception developed by the texts of staff and TEU (theoretical conception) is consistent with independent evidence supported by texts authored by the administration and critical scholarship.

Assigning identity

Students, staff, and the administration negotiate who may claim the identity of UoA. The debate over the ‘University of Auckland’ keyword is not new (We are the University Auckland, 2011a, 2011b, 2013, 2017) or unique to UoA (Moran, 2014; Ghoussoub, 2014; Jones, 2012). Some administrations even encourage student participation in university identity and control (Peseta et al., 2021). Identity bounds define who may claim ownership of the university’s accomplishments and impose their ideals on the institution. Currently, UoA is considered successful in many ways. The administration disproportionately consolidates surplus into administrative positions, like Vice-Chancellor Dawn Freshwater, who captures $755,000 annually (Ewert, 2021; Leahy, 2021). Conversely, staff work and live in precarity (Simpson et al., 2022; Galic, 2019; Stringer et al., 2018), particularly those who are intersectionality disadvantaged (Barber & Naepi, 2020). The assumed power of the administration, and associated economic inequities, are fundamentally challenged by establishing students and staff as the essence of the institution’s success.

Academic conception

The academic conception perceives students and staff as the essence of universities (see: TEUVUW; Tamika Glouftsis; Cor Vink; Steve Gallagher; Dean Knight; Sandra Grey; Emmy Rākete; Emmy Rākete; Marnie Lloydd; Eddie Clark; Eddie Clark; Giulio Valentino Dalla Rivavdr). This perspective aligns with the labour theory of value, in which the sum value of the university is equivalent to the socially necessary labour time to create it (Marx, 1845). The vast majority of university labour time is delegated to professional and academic staff, whose combined labour totalled 5641 FTE (full-time equivalent) in 2021 (The University of Auckland [Administration], 2021) compared to the eight total staff employed in the management team (The University of Auckland [Administration], n.d.-b).

Administrative conception

Due to their position of power, the UoA administration imposes a specific conception of the university, defining the goals and systems of the institution. One example is the introduction of capitalist ideals of ‘entrepreneurialism’ into the institution’s structure. In 2013 the UoA administration redefined the role of an academic to be one of ‘leadership’, identified as an ideological misnomer of entrepreneurship (Lewis & Shore, 2017). The descriptor of academics as ‘entrepreneurial’ is used by university administrations much more frequently than academics, whose stances on their identity differed, indicating more ideological negotiation than the term’s dominance would imply (Holborow, 2012).

Marnie Holborow (2012) identifies the flexibility of ‘entrepreneurship’, where definitions have shifted from ‘masters of success’ to ‘navigators’ of unknown depths during economic downturns. Entrepreneurships’ demand for economic success devolved into creative risk-taking and innovation. Entrepreneurship does not contain a skillset, only successful gambles (Holborow, 2012). Once capital drained exploitable resources, entrepreneurial definitions of success shifted in line with the failures of capitalism. Neoliberalism even re-semanticists it into social services as ‘social entrepreneurship’.

The administrative conception of UoA represses staff who choose to strike from identity. The administrative exclusion of protesting staff implies that disagreeing with management is identity severing, and thus staff only wield the identity if they hold no power, therefore, cannot wield the university’s identity. The administration states, “University of Auckland has expressed disappointment that the TEU and PSA have chosen to strike” (The University of Auckland [Administration], 2022, para. 1). This language abstracts the process of the strike decision in which the staff struck, not only union management. Separating the identities of staff from UoA is inconsistent with existing statements by the administration. The ‘Key Statistics’ webpage uses the following language to describe the university’s success in securing research funding:

In the most recent (2018) evaluation, the University of Auckland:

  • Had 33% of the top rated researchers in the whole country
  • Gained 31% of the funding based on research degree completions and 33% of the funding based on external research income
  • Gained 30% of the funding overall, thereby confirming its position as the nation’s premier research institution (The University of Auckland [Administration], n.d., para. 2)

Specifically, the portrayal of the ‘University of Auckland’ gaining funding implies that the identity is held, in part, by those responsible for acquiring funding. However, according to both the administration’s academic standards document (The University of Auckland [Administration], n.d.-a) and a report commissioned by the TEU (Business and Economic Research Limited, 2022), the responsibility of procuring research funding rests upon academic faculty. The severance of staff who decided to strike from the identity of UoA, as well as the sharing of identity with those who capture research funding, is logically inconsistent with the administration’s expectation for academic staff to procure research funding. The administration’s messaging is ideologically convenient, using keywords to enforce the will of the administration and disenfranchise staff, maintaining the power of the administration.

This misrepresentation of the values held by the administration obscures the value and labour of staff. The inconsistent narration of the university identity demonstrates the UoA administration as producing contradictory and ideological discourse depending on the convenience of the situation. With compromised credibility, the UoA administration is an unreliable narrator, which is also contradictory to the values the administration claims to hold: “We act with integrity, openness and honesty at all times” (The University of Auckland [Administration], n.d.-d, para. 12).

Results of the neoliberal academe

The contradiction of values and actions

The administration suppressing staff and severing their identity from the university is directly oppositional to the claim of “[being] values-led in our relationships, creating genuine opportunities for the communities we serve to engage in ethical and responsible partnerships” (The University of Auckland [Administration], n.d.-d, para. 13). Similar contradictions are throughout administrative values and (in)actions in marketing and policy documents. Universities New Zealand, a coalition of university administrations, complained that “2022 [government] funding doesn’t even keep up with inflation” (Universities New Zealand, 2022, para. 1), justifying wage suppression of staff “while retaining fiscal responsibility” (The University of Auckland [Administration], 2022a). The UoA administration proposes, “This offer has been carefully costed and while it is a stretch, it is sustainable” (Dawn Freshwater as quoted in The University of Auckland [Administration], 2022b, para. 5). However, the academic conceptions present a different reality:

universities could afford the increase. They all claim poverty but they've all got money in the bank. (TEU Massey Wellington president Leon Salter as quoted in Gerritsen & Walton, 2022)

For two years we really believed that the university was in a difficult position and we worked really hard in good faith to support the work of the university and for them to come to us again this year and to offer nothing it's like why did we believe you last year and how could this keep going on." (Tutor Sam Bigwood as quoted in Gerritsen & Walton, 2022)

It's just not credible that they can't afford to pay staff a wage increase that is in line with inflation. (TEU Bargaining team member Antonia Verstappen as quoted in Gerritsen & Walton, 2022)

Furthermore, when given the backing and a proposal for more funding to address higher learner ratios, increasingly casualised employment, recruiting problems, staff turnover, workloads concern, and exploitation of teaching assistants, both Universities New Zealand and UoA administration declined (Tertiary Education Union, 2022; See also: Dougal McNeill; Daniel Benson-Guiu; Dean Knight).

We now seek an urgent meeting between the chancellors, TEU, and the Minister of Education to canvas a tripartite response to the impact this deliberate disinvestment in staffing and the risk it poses to all universities and their ability to deliver the educated workforce Aotearoa will need for the future. We also believe a tripartite meeting is the way to strategise how we can ensure staff conditions of work are of a standard which ensures high-quality conditions of learning. It is only together that we can find the best way forward. (Tertiary Education Union, 2022a)

We would welcome an opportunity to meet and work with you and your constituent institutions to secure more funding for the university sector for all of the above reasons. One approach could be to jointly call for a tripartite forum between TEU, Universities New Zealand, and the government. This approach has been successful in securing funding boosts in the past. (Tertiary Education Union, 2022b)

Though we clearly both agree that there is a funding challenge, we are not convinced that a tripartite forum of the sort you suggest is likely to be effective. At a headline level we will always agree that greater investment is needed in universities, but we are likely to have very different views as to where that investment is going to make the greatest difference. (Universities New Zealand, 2022a)

These are individual employment matters which need to be addressed at a local level rather than collectively. Each institution will have its own nuances to these issues and varying financial positions as to how they can respond. While I agree that there are funding challenges, I share the view of the Vice-Chancellors that the tripartite meeting you suggest is not likely to be effective. (The University of Auckland [Administration], 2022a)

Manaakitanga

Te Tiriti o Waitangi obligations require universities to enact manaakitanga (Bishop et al., 2009). However, institutions often reduce it to notions of hospitality rather than valuing people beyond productive output and collectivised responsibility (K.I.N. Author Collective, 2021). The UoA administration makes such reductions of their core values, defined limitedly as “Caring for those around us in the way we relate to each other” (The University of Auckland [Administration], n.d.-d, para. 4). Proudly emphasised across UoA policy documents and marketing (see: The University of Auckland [Administration], n.d.-d; The University of Auckland Faculty of Education and Social Work, 2021; The University of Auckland [Administration], 2020a), not only do the aspirations of the administration fall short of the academic conceptions of manaakitanga, their implementation is worse, if not entirely counterproductive.

Managerialism

Identified in the strike discourse, “the neoliberal university is the risk university. The highest level of decision making is often made by risk managers” (Dutta, 2022, para. 2). This transformation into a financial institution that trades in various capitals correlates with disproportionately increasing administrative costs, which are, in turn, increasingly opaque to researchers (Rhoades, 1998b; Business and Economic Research Limited, 2022). The separation of professional and academic staff obscures the intersectional work done by both (Rhoades, 1998b). Gary Rhoades (1998b) prompts an accountable institution via disaggregation of accounting, but the UoA administration further obscures information with separate bargaining processes (The University of Auckland [Administration], 2022d).

UoA reflects a history of power struggles over the institution. With proportionately fewer academic staff (Figure 1), power over the university has eroded from academic to administrative positions (Rhoades, 1998a), increasingly focused on commercialisation via UniServices Ltd. We can see that the administration evaluates an academic’s work through capitalist cost-benefit analysis or ‘accountability’, where academics and institutions must prove their worth (Rhoades, 1998a). However, these processes, particularly performance indicators, have been established to be non-causal to society’s betterment (Bruneau & Savage, 2004). By failing to account for research complexities as counterproductive, policies are introduced, such as divestment from academic work (Bruneau & Savage, 2004).

Increasingly opaque administrative practice at universities externalises accountability to the labour union that conducts independent research into university operations (see: BERL). However, an analysis commissioned by TEU has shown that there has been a deliberate shift in policy to proportionately disinvest in staff personnel costs (Tertiary Education Union, 2022a). Such choices by university administrations develop structures of precarity that structurally prevent staff well-being.

Structural precarity and un-wellbeing

University administrations do not embody manaakitanga in their employment relationships, demonstrated by the conceptions of their relationship with staff. According to the academic conception of UoA, staff are underpaid and overworked in precarious employment. The UoA administration offered a ‘Voluntary Leaving Scheme’ to minimise staff expenses during the pandemic (Collins, 2020a; New Zealand Mathematical Society, 2020). Vulnerability manufactured by greedy financial strategies dependent on exporting education (Chance, 2022), leading to 82 terminations in 2020 and 161 terminations in 2021 (The University of Auckland [Administration], 2021) of experienced researchers (Tina Smith as cited in Gerritsen, 2021a). Such “little strategic leadership, [and] so much cognitive dissonance” (Hall, 2020, p. 358) left workloads amplified and real wages lowered, socialising the costs of administrative greed. The administration’s intentional defunding exploits faculty further (Tina Smith as cited in Gerritsen, 2021a), is dehumanising for staff, and harms students’ learning (See: Cassie), despite financial surplus and record enrolments during the pandemic (Gerritsen, 2022a, The University of Auckland [Administration], 2021).

University administrations “slashed the hours of hundreds and possibly thousands of people with casual lecturing and tutoring roles since the pandemic began” (Gerritsen, 2022b, para. 27). The UoA administration claims they are “committed to enhancing the participation and success of Māori and equity groups [...] through removing barriers” (The University of Auckland [Administration], 2020b, para. 7), yet demanded that the staff of the New Start programme work for free. The New Start programme supports 50-100 majority Māori and Pasifika adults from disadvantaged backgrounds to enter university annually (Collins, 2020b, para. 2).

Working hours

In the academic conception of UoA, financial catastrophisation is identified (see: Dean Knight) as a mechanism of suppressing wages and supported by documentation by the UoA administration, which, “according to page 78 of its annual report, made after tax profit of over $100,000,000 last year” (Union striker in Gerritsen & Walton, 2022; The University of Auckland [Administration], 2021). Increased domestic enrollment boosted the net student tuition fees for UoA, the University of Canterbury, and Auckland University of Technology in 2020 (Gerritsen, 2021b, para. 5).

Downsizing personnel has increased student-staff ratios, broadened usage of limited and casualised employment, hindered recruiting staff, increased workloads, and increased reliance on teaching fellows/graduate teaching assistants, jeopardising academic and support service quality (Tertiary Education Union, 2022a). Workloads for academic staff are increasing (see: Cassie) and are generally under-recognised, including for the lowest-paid academic staff, tutors (Tertiary Education Union, n.d.). The pandemic exacerbated these issues, almost doubling already unsustainable workloads for many (Tertiary Education Union, n.d.). The pandemic also harmed the working conditions of academic employees (see: N, Dean Knight), whose complaints are suppressed by administrations (see: Jo) rather than addressing staff concerns how they need them addressed (see: Sam), a trope of poor disaster leadership (Matthewman, 2015).

Staff commonly identified they worked hours beyond their contracts, aligning with existing research where 66% of NZ academic staff work above contracted hours (Simpson et al., 2022). Over-working rates increased significantly during the pandemic: (2022; see also: Sam White; Bex). There is an expectation that teaching assistants, as students, should suffer academically and financially (See Chels). In these conditions, it is no wonder a TEU survey reports that 85% of all academic staff are experiencing moderate to high stress (Tertiary Education Union, n.d.).

Financial compensation

While NZ’s Education Act (1989) has mitigated administrative repression of academics, the intentional degradation of worker rights enables administrations to repress criticism through financial dominance, mitigating opportunities for a radical reconstruction of higher education. Identifying these processes is paramount for maintaining a critical and socially beneficial conception of education and society (Freire, 1970).

Negotiating with the TEU bargaining team, university administrations refuse to maintain wages with inflation. The UoA administration provided a supposed 'best offer' of, in real terms, a 2.3% (1% for those earning <$60,000) pay cut and what is likely to be cut in 2024, conditional on a withdrawal of retirement gratuity and long service leave entitlements (The University of Auckland [Administration], 2022b). The administration provided no accounting with their 'best offer' distinction, another form of obscurity that the administration weaponises against staff. The administration's clawbacks are justified with language that suppresses their responsibility for precarious employment: "We want to reward people now and not at the end of their careers. We don't think it's fair to offer benefits that many staff will never receive" (The University of Auckland [Administration], 2022b, para. 5).

The TEU demands an 8% pay rise for its 7000 members (RNZ, 2022), citing the need to keep up with the 7.3% consumer price index increase in 2022 (Stats NZ, 2022). The union communicated concerns about pay reduction to the UoA administration and the media, "we're just trying to make sure that our members can pay their bills" (Sandra Grey, as quoted in RNZ, 2022). A report commissioned by the TEU found that, since 2007, average salaries at the UoA have fallen behind inflation by 17% (Business and Economic Research Limited, 2022). University staff rallied around the call for an 8% increase to keep up with inflation. Many critiqued the weak proposals from the university (see: Siouxsie Wiles [Appendix #1]; Sam White, Jo Bailey, Sandra Grey, Dean Knight, Callie, Jack Heinemann, Dougal McNeill, Erin Burrell, Dean Knight, Alexander, Erica Fosk, @noflightfairy).

Most wage discussions involved the desire for a living wage for all university staff and an 8% general increase to cover inflation. Most affected by the absence of a living wage are teaching assistants, graduate teaching assistants, and research assistants (Simpson et al., 2022). A living wage is a minimum remuneration sufficient to maintain the labourer (Werner & Lim, 2015). Failing to provide a living wage is a failure to provide decency to the university staff. Presently NZ academic qualifications are subsidised by exploiting fellow precarious students.

Strikers identified that supermarkets now pay better than graduate teaching assistant roles at Victoria University of Wellington (see: Grant Jun Otsuki; Lisa Te Morengaf), this is also true for UoA teaching assistants (The University of Auckland [Administration] & Tertiary Education Union, 2019). Not having a living wage prevents staff from living with dignity (see: Priyanka Dhopade) and externalises labour costs onto the worker, family, community, and government. Lisa Te Morenga (2022) documented how Māori communities subsidised university te reo courses that her son taught, despite his six years of te reo education.

The conditions of precarious employment vary, but the account given by New Zealand academics aligns with the provisions provided by the International Labour Organisation:

The expansion of temporary forms of employment has received a great deal of attention in recent years. Their development has been associated with fears that it may enshrine dual labour markets where employers would increasingly only provide permanent status to core employees, while maintaining a pool of more dispensable workers with no security, low wages, poor benefits, and little chance of professional advancement. (International Labour Organization, 2011, p. 8)

(See also: Cassie; Kate Lee; Siouxsie Wiles [Appendix #1]; Dougal McNeill; Callie; @lovelydizon_; Callie; Andrew Chen; Erica Fosk; Sylvia Nissen; Morgan Godfery; Emmy Rākete; Bex Graham; Erica Fosk; Avery Smit).

According to the academic conception, such polarisation of employment security is getting worse (see: Priyanka Dhopade), and such fragile contracts are working to undermine academic freedom as provided by the 1989 Education Act (see: Mohan Dutta), in addition to staff’s ability to engage in worker solidarity (Catherine). Academics propose solutions stating, “kaimahi need increased staffing levels to ease workloads, and end to stressful restructuring, more professional development and decent research and study leave.”(Tertiary Education Union, 2022b, para. 6). Precarious work conditions are increasingly encroaching on all staff demographics inducing stress (Simpson et al., 2022). The BERL data finds that operating expenses have increased since 2008, but the slowest growth in expenditure has been on staff costs (Tertiary Education Union, 2022a), while staff also “face the highest inflation in three decades” (Tertiary Education Union, 2022b).

The pandemic has only increased workloads and stress for university staff, who are feeling the effects of an ever-increasing obligation to secure research revenue (Business and Economic Research Limited, 2022; RNZ, 2022), as well as ongoing under-investment in staff, and ever-increasing spending on assets, like buildings and renovations. Such “Deliberate decisions to disinvest in labour dehumanises University workers, our whānau and wider community” (Cassie, 2022), resulting in calls for the administration to “Live your claimed values” (Virginia, 2022). The negotiation of university investment is demonstrated excellently by a tweet from AUT, “our world-class facilities, state-of-the-art buildings & student services provide our AUT whānau with a supportive & collaborative learning environment” (Auckland University of Technology [Administration], 2022), and staff reply, “what about the old job losses and threatening your staff for two weeks without pay?!” (McAllister, 2022b).

In the style of a cartoon villain, three years of major demolition and reconstruction for the UoA recreation centre has banished natural light from several faculty offices. The NZ Mathematical Society provided noise-cancelling headphones for members to compensate for the UoA administration's failures (New Zealand Mathematical Society, 2020).

University administrations have created ideological interpretations of 'well-being' that individualise responsibility for administrative shortcomings. Further diluting radical keywords with ideology and suppressing staff calls for investment into structural interventions. The UoA administration expects staff to coordinate student well-being (Campus Life, 2019) without establishing student-administration relationships to truly empower change in the structural conditions of staff and students. Participants in the striking discourse have identified structural conditions which contribute to staff and student un-wellbeing, tactics of the administration to performatively address the issues, and avoiding the conditions which enable this phenomenon (see: Sereana). By invoking resilience narratives, the administration individualises the consequences of its failures to make the university a healthy workplace and attempts to cement the systematic failures of the institution against narratives that challenge the status quo.

There are spaces of academic resistance to the administration's responsibilisation of individuals for well-being. These spaces seek to rearticulate the issue of well-being with a critical focus on the systems which enable un-wellbeing. Consequently, universities are at risk of losing what makes their institutions valuable (Tina Smith in RNZ Checkpoint, 2022, para. 20, See also: CriticalMassAKL), reflected by calls across learners and teachers that "Staff working conditions are student learning conditions" (Tertiary Education Union Auckland, 2022; See also: Barley et al., 2022; Hopkins, 2022; Cassie; Callie).

The administrative response

Repression

The repression of staff concerns are identified by several academics. For example, Tara McAllister (2022a) identifies the minimisation of staff concerns and the structural inequalities of the university environment. Sam White (2022b) identifies explicitly the double-speak of Lincoln University’s Vice Chancellor, who acknowledges the value and labour of staff but fails to recognise the universities obligation and relation in response.

The academic conception generally finds the university to be a valuable institution, and the staff who struck expressed a preference to be working. Hence, the strike was not about struggles with the university, it was with the relationships and priorities of the administrations (see: Kate Lee; Sam White; Emmy Rākete Siouxsie Wiles [Appendix #1]; Nadia; Dougal McNeill; Cate Macinnis-Ng; Dean Knight). The administrations do not value the staff, reflected in the contradictions presented by the administrative conception. The narrative that the administration provides of their values, such as manaakitanga, would align with the desires of the staff. However, we find that the purported values of the administration are not accurate.

The discourse offered by administrations does not engage with the conditions of employment they offer. Instead, administrations suppress the realities of their actions (see: Tara McAllister, 2022a; 2022b; Sam White, 2022b). Conclusively, the goals of neoliberal university administration are fundamentally oppositional to that of staff when they operate as businesses. The administration’s promotion of ideological structures undermines staff concerns rather than collaborating with staff to resolve the issue (see: Sereana Naepi; Emmy Rākete; Callie).

Universities New Zealand, representing university administrations, was contacted by the TEU in an attempt to organise tripartite negotiations with the government, but they declined the opportunity stating:

Though we clearly both agree that there is a funding challenge, we are not convinced that a tripartite forum of the sort you suggest is likely to be effective. At a headline level we will always agree that greater investment is needed in universities, but we are likely to have very different views as to where that investment is going to make the greatest difference. (The University of Auckland [Administration], 2022a)

Distortion

The administration suppresses the reality of staff as it subverts the ideology they produce. The UoA administration catastrophised the pandemic’s financial impact, presented as “terrible, awful, and unbearable [but] in reality is merely inconvenient or uncomfortable” (Didier Fassin & Pandolfi, 2010, p. 40, see: Dean Knight). Discursive catastrophisation legitimises emergency states of dramatic redistribution of resources and obligations (Didier Fassin & Pandolfi, 2010). The UoA administration’s catastrophisation of financial capacity supposedly justified significant cuts to the resourcing of critical education (Grant, 2020). This is despite increased enrollments with a net $7,000,000 surplus in 2020 (Gerritsen, 2021b), which increased to a $133,000,000 surplus in 2021 (Gerritsen, 2022a). Catastrophisation allowed for the decimation of the social sciences, halving third-year study options, cutting tutoring positions, and overall harming the ability of the university to utilise critical pedagogy and develop critical consciousness (Grant, 2020).

Neoliberal university operations consolidate wealth into the managerial class. UoA Vice-Chancellor Dawn Freshwater captures $755,000 every year (Leahy, 2021), and the wages of the deputy and pro-vice chancellors are obscured (Cam & Dan, 2020). The hypocrisy of cutting resources to tutors and research assistants (Nikki Hessell; Peter Beaver), the lowest-paid academic staff, while consolidating so much wealth aligns deeply with the subtle and continual assertion by the administration that staff do not possess or contribute to the value and identity of the university. Calling the bluff of manipulative catastrophisation for exploiting fear is dutied to an enlightened, politically aware public. They must ensure that leadership does not (pretend to) suffer from catastrophising anxieties (Didier Fassin & Pandolfi, 2010).

The academic conception of the administration identifies a pattern of deceit in neoliberal administrative communications and behaviours, which may constitute a breaking of ‘good faith’ as outlined in NZ employment law (Employment New Zealand, n.d.). Further, the culture of manipulation for self-interest expands beyond the strike, threatening the critical essence of the university.

Performative justice

Neoliberal hegemony counters the demand for new structures. The UoA administration theatrically embraces the values and terminology of critical scholarship (see: The University of Auckland [Administration], 2022c) but practically suppresses alternative ways of being. The responses to indigenous epistemologies and scholarship demonstrate the suppression of radical alternatives. Indigenous scholars identify neoliberal logic as the contemporary toolkit of imperialism (Kidman, 2019). NZ universities, modelled on British universities, perpetuate Eurocentric education in the interests of a mono-cultural elite despite Te Tiriti o Waitangi obligations to enact manaakitanga (Bishop et al., 2009). Therefore, they have little regard for Māori pedagogy, history, or discourse (K.I.N. Author Collective, 2021). Our inequitable social outcomes demonstrate the influence of neoliberal ideologies in maintaining racial hierarchies (New Zealand Parliament, 2012). The disregard for indigenous scholars and students’ well-being (Ahenakew, 2016, p. 323) produces an underrepresentation of Māori in NZ universities and “ethnic inequalities [keep] increasing as levels of academic seniority increase” (Naepi et al., 2020, p. 146; K.I.N. Author Collective, 2021).

 

Tuck and Yang (2012) describe settler ‘moves towards innocence’ as the actions institutions take to minimise moral responsibility for colonial systems of power, such as the dilution of ‘decolonisation’ through metaphorical usage. Moves towards innocence mask patterns of advantage. Administrations selectively and theatrically embrace indigenous research, which affirms their public identities and empowers their position as thought leaders (Ahenakew, 2016; Kidman, 2019) while rejecting true decolonial liberation (Ahenakew, 2016). In this way, universities establish cultural capital for engaging with indigenous ways of being. However, it is a trick. Extending the colonial social structure, UoA provides inequitable outcomes for tāngata whenua (The University of Auckland – Planning and Information Office & Equity Office, 2018; Naepi et al., 2020). The administration downplays its responsibility (Tuck & Yang, 2012) with discursive power, which maintains public silence about the colonial past and its consequences in the present (Kidman, 2019).

We can trace how university administrations manage dissonance by considering universities’ so-called decolonial efforts. Accepting the gifted name of Waipapa Taumata Rau from Ngāti Whātua Ōrākei and labelling manaakitanga, kaitiakitanga and whanaungatanga as “ideas important to the University” (The University of Auckland [Administration], 2020c), provide the university with the aesthetics of indigeneity. However, decentering settler values are not equivalent to decolonial outcomes (Tuck & Yang, 2012). Critical analysis of the UoA administration’s communications highlights the implementation of discursive power, which wipes its hands of responsibility to structurally address the ongoing suppression and appropriation of Māori scholars, scholarship, and values (as discussed in the sections on findings). In Defence of Science (Clements et al., 2021) demonstrates racism harboured and fostered in academia (Ngata, 2021). In response to the outrage, the university administration declared that “the letter did not represent the university’s views” (Henry, 2021, para. 7), again premised on an ideological separation of staff and UoA identity, suppressing the conditions the administration creates to foster such perspectives.

Neoliberal university administrations demobilise alternatives by systematically under-resourcing critical scholarship and suppressing, misinterpreting, and performing decoloniality rather than changing systematically. These actions are grounded in long-understood systems of domination used by capital to suppress alternative ways of being.

The gimmick

The patterns of administrative ideology are comical, i.e. they produce a gimmick, a tricky device adopted to attract attention or publicity (Ngai, 2017). A gimmick is attractive because it seems truly valuable, but is frustrating because it is fundamentally an aesthetic misjudgement that only partially succeeds (2017).

The consistent appropriation of critical frameworks, such as well-being (Harward, 2016), indigeneity, and feminism (Blackmore, 2017), produces “a quick but immediately vanishing aesthetic payoff, one that cannot begin a project or sustain a tradition” (Ngai, 2017, p. 483). Each administrative intervention is tractionless, remaining inherently self-contained (Ngai, 2017). The gimmick is dismissed out of overfamiliarity with its deployment, thus, nothing has changed, no value has been produced. The administration produces “novelty with no consequences beyond its immediately vanishing moment” (Ngai, 2017, p. 483). By presenting as if radical, and then failing to be, the UoA administration elicits the contradictions of neoliberal capitalism.

Conclusion

Neoliberalism, and therefore neoliberal university administrations, demand ignorance for ideological mastery. Administrations guide the university in the pursuit of extraction, providing unreliable narrations to consolidate power for the capitalist and managerial classes. Just as the entrepreneur is psychotic in failing to recognise the "value, the work and time of others" (Santisteban & Jones, 2022, p. 3), so too is the neoliberal university administration, suppressing the realities of staff, faculty, and students through various moves to innocence. The UoA administration is disingenuous with its financial narratives, inducing catastrophisation to suppress wages. Their manipulations are empowered through opaque accounting, intentionally not standard between institutions. Neoliberal administrations undermine the public value of universities and work to limit academic labour's capability to transform higher education by appropriating genuine critical frameworks and transforming them into gimmicks.

Recognising the bad faith of the neoliberal administration has two primary consequences: academics may focus on their scholarship and praxis for higher education futures rather than negotiate with the administration's ideology, and authorities can turn to more reliable narratives, such as those offered by academics, to establish measures of university success. This documentation resources a more significant power shift from administrations toward the staff that form the university so that we may conceive of higher education otherwise.
